Description: Most of body of wheel-made pottery black-glazed oil lamp; flattened globular body and an inward-sloping rim defined by a groove; long tapering flat-topped nozzle (largel;y missing); the horizontal strap handle is also missing. Covered with a metallic black glaze, fired red in places. Fine orange fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Leiden University, Faculty of Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Athens (Howland 1958, 66, Type 25A, dated 375BC-275BC, or Type 24C, pl. 37-38, pl.9) and Corinth (Broneer 1930, 45-46, Type VII, pl.III, fig. 120; 32, fig. 14). Late 4th or 3rd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Blondé 1998, 313-4, no. 1). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée D’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35. Broneer, O. 1930. Corinth IV.II, Terracotta lamps, Princeton. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.39) (Phase 3)
van de Wiel 1968 / Verzameling ceramiek en Terracotta's Archaeologisch Instituut der Rijksuniversiteit Leiden (p. 14, N 46)
